Tucson knew that the insects would attempt to follow him in the air, and wi=
th sword in hand, he attempts to use a revolving swing of the blade in thei=
r directions, hoping to clip them of their wings. 

"Thank you Vestige!  I =
think I can handle it from here."

--- In nbwrpg@yahoogroups.com, Preston C=
arroll <supercyclonus@...> wrote:

 Vestige, as he slowly backs himself onto the other end of the catapult. He=
 quickly turns back to the insects and positions himself to prepare for fli=
ght. He wastes no time in giving the signal to implement his attempt to go =
airbourne.
> >
> > " NOW!"
> 
> Vestige looked confused for the moment as i=
t was *he* that needed to
> unite with the figure on the bed. But it was on=
ly a passing confusion
> as he shrugged slightly, stepped off the metal and=
 let Tuscon on. With
> a blast of firepower he held off the approaching ins=
ectoids as he
> cartwheeled to one side landing in a crouched position, his=
 weapon hot
> and smoking as it continued to lay down the needed cover fire=
. A quick
> glance at it showed him that it was begining to run low, this b=
attle
> would need to end soon, or else . . .
> 
> As Tuscon mounted the me=
tal and positioned it properly, Vestige leaped
> from his position, sprang =
through the air, and with grim determination
> landed squarly on the others=
ide sending Tuscon sailing through the air
> in the direction of the figure=
 on the bed, who had up to this time had
> some how remained clear of all t=
he weapon's fire! No doubt that that
> would soon change with Tuscon moving=
 quickly in his direction.
> 
> As Tuscon moved through the air the insecto=
ids attempted to follow
> him, a spray of metal and energy following him in=
 a focused swath of
> destuctive power. Then with deadly precision the flyi=
ng insectiods

 close in
